solution_line_template: If the 1st fastest dog is {age_1st_dog} years old, and the 2nd fastest dog is {age_difference_2nd_dog} years younger than the first fastest dog, the 2nd fastest dog is {age_1st_dog}-{age_difference_2nd_dog}=<<{age_1st_dog}-{age_difference_2nd_dog}={age_2nd_dog}>>{age_2nd_dog} years old.
The 3rd fastest dog being {age_increase_3rd_dog} years older than the 2nd fastest dog, is {age_2nd_dog}+{age_increase_3rd_dog}={age_3rd_dog} years old.
The 4th fastest dog is half the age of the 3rd fastest dog, meaning the 4th fastest dog is 1/{half_factor}*{age_3rd_dog}={age_4th_dog} years old.
The 5th fastest dog is {age_increase_5th_dog} years older than the 4th fastest dog, meaning the 5th fastest dog is {age_4th_dog}+{age_increase_5th_dog}={age_5th_dog} years old.
The total age of the 1st and 5th fastest dogs is {age_5th_dog}+{age_1st_dog}=<<{age_5th_dog}+{age_1st_dog}={total_age_1st_5th_dogs}>>{total_age_1st_5th_dogs} years

The average age of the 1st and 5th fastest dogs is {total_age_1st_5th_dogs}/{number_of_dogs_for_average}=<<{total_age_1st_5th_dogs}/{number_of_dogs_for_average}={average_age}>>{average_age} years old.
